job_title: Instructional Student Aid in San Luis Obispo, CA
pros: Flexible hours - your professor will usually work with your schedule
cons:
Not enough hours to make enough money to support myself during the academic year (only about 20-40 hours per quarter). I needed another part time job on top of this. 

Hours are not evenly distributed between every week of the quarter. Some weeks you may have no grading or the professor may not need assistance. Other weeks (closer to midterms and finals), you may need to provide several hours.

job_title: Part Time Faculty in Fullerton, CA
pros: It was great working with the students and staff. Actually, that was the highlight of the experience. Teaching can be very fun and rewarding, especially seeing how bright, creative, and enthusiastic the students are.
cons: The paydates are just weird (start teaching in August, but the first paycheck comes in October), and the mandatory training is a one-size-fits-all approach that can be overbearing. The testing and grading system transferred to being online only, but the testing system was not easy to manage and had a steep learning curve.

job_title: Associate Professor in San Jose, CA
pros: This is the place where your academic career will die.  Academic freedom and free inquiry are facades.  Dissent and alternate views are stifled, the administration lies to new faculty recruits to get them in, salary is sub-par, so many of my peers have been absolutely crushed by this place. Administration is corrupt and spends their time covering each other up instead of fixing the systematic problems.  Come here if you want to keep your head down, do your job, and not make any waves.  Most of the students are ill-prepared to take your course, and none of your colleagues will be willing to challenge them because "they're not bright enough" (yes, faculty here actually say that about the students).  Best described by another faculty member I know as "an overgrown high school."  If you are stupid, noisy, incompetent, and excel at doing pointless tasks that make you look good on paper while being a deficit to everyone around you, you will fit right in.  If you can think for yourself and you want to change things and enrich this university, your time (and career) is better spent someplace else.
cons: You cannot even fathom how dysfunctional this place is.  This university also has the tendency of making you feel trapped.... If you stay here too long, you will feel like you're not good enough to be accepted anywhere else.  You will feel like you are trapped here. It will crush your very sole.  I know far too many faculty across multiple departments who feel this way.  The hallmarks of an abusive relationship.

job_title: Social Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Perfectly perfect place to eork
cons: Great memories and grace of the time

job_title: Cyberinfrastructure Manager in Santa Rosa, CA
pros:
Good people
Hard work ethic
Meaningful mission
Great benefits
cons: the pay could be more aligned with industry standards

job_title: Tutor in Fullerton, CA
pros: Flexible Schedule, and good friendly work environment
cons: limit to 20 hours for pert time student workers

review_title: Service to the State of California and local communities
job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working in the CSU system has its benefits: campuses try to collaborate, people have a service-oriented mindset, and often the students are local. The Cal State system values service to underserved populations and minorities, champions those who have less, and provides free tutoring and other student support services. As an employee, the benefits package is exceptional compared to most state systems. In addition, most campuses are in beautiful areas - so you feel fortunate to live in that city.
cons: Perhaps because of the recent economic recession, the Cal State system is understaffed. That means "wearing" many hats - sometimes well outside of one's job description, and working long hours. In addition, there aren't any raises. In general the focus in on  great student service, some consideration for faculty concerns, but little attention for staff or administration needs. Essentially the cost of living and increasing taxes whittles away are the average income until the viability of continuing to live in an area and/or retiring seems more and more remote.

job_title: Web Designer/Interface Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: There is a family atmosphere at CSU. It's not flashy, or high-paid, but the health and retirement benefits are great. Staff and Faculty can join the clubs on campus. I was a member of the sailing club, which is one of the happiest times in my life, full of great memories. If you believe that people who work blue-collar jobs should be paid as much as people who work white-collar jobs, then you will fit right in.
cons: If you believe that skilled work that requires a high level of education, creativity, critical thinking, and innovation should be encouraged through a merit-based payment structure that competes with the rest of the nation, do not apply.

review_title: This place is NOT a meritocracy
job_title: Administrative Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros: Not much work expected after hours.  Also the staff development funding and time is pretty generous.  I've never had a conference or training request turned down.
cons: There's no incentive to do things well or to care too much.  Performance reviews are a joke, and have no bearing on any raises or promotions, so there's no accountability.  If you think you deserve a promotion, you have to wait and wait for an opening to be posted, apply, and go through a whole interview process (unless you're somehow in management, they get promotions much more often, and it's not always based on talent/quality of work).  There are just too many people here counting down the years until they retire, so nobody's thinking of systems/technology/etc. for the long-term.  Very frustrating.

job_title: Associate Professor in San Jose, CA
pros: Right now, you can get away with a schedule teaching 2 days a week, and be away from this hell hole for the rest of the time (even though you will do plenty of work at home, if you're not on campus, it never ceases!)
cons: Shitty salary.  And there haven't been any raises in 6 years.  And our idiot union even decided to give up on step increases altogether, meaning you will only get two raises of 7.5% each, one with each of two promotions, throughout your entire career.  Considering our graduates typically earn more than they pay us, and cost of living is continuing to skyrocket, this is untenable.  A lot of good people leave, and a lot of complacent people stay.  If good people stay too long, they end up just not caring.  Want to go to a conference?  Try waiting six months (or longer!) for your travel reimbursement.

job_title: Auditor in Long Beach, CA
pros:
-Pay is decent for a government job if you know your worth.
-Great benefits as expected from a government job.
-Generous vacation policy, comparable to public accounting.
-Pay for CIA certification study materials and test fees if passed.
-Auditors are nice, easy to get along with.
-Not stressful if you plan correctly. 
-Free coffee and filtered water?
cons:
-Travel to sometimes the middle of nowhere M-F with no real flexibility. Be prepared to get home late Friday nights.
-Management expects a lot of face time at the campuses. Most of the work can be done remotely. It is unnecessary to travel to campuses for 5 weeks per audit when all documentation is received electronically anyway. 
-Top-down hierarchy and micromanagement.
-Their way is the only right way to do things. Don't bring any new suggestions or ideas, just nod your head and agree with everything.
-Paragraphs of word-by-word interview notes are expected. No bullet points with main ideas because efficiency is frowned upon.
-Getting caught up in little insignificant details rather than looking at the big picture.

job_title: Tenured Professor in Fullerton, CA
pros:
Great education facilities
Strong student body
cons:
Part-time instructors are overused in order to keep costs low and to avoid having to deal with union benefits for full-time instructors.

Also, the Cal State policy on health care insurance is broken--or at least is easily exploited by departments (with the direct knowledge of deans and higher in mgmt.) If you teach 2 classes one semester, you can get health insurance--a big deal given the Obamacare problems in roll out. If your classes drop to 1 for a semester (something that a part-time instructor has no control over), you suddenly lose the health insurance. If it goes back up to 2, you can get it again.

This creates a scenario where instructors can (and HAVE) gained insurance, then lost it, then gained it again, then lost it. By the time you apply and wait for the month to turn over so you are covered, you can literally have insurance for 3 months and then lose it again. An absolutely TRAVESTY of a policy.

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in Carson, CA
pros: The CSU provides a world-class education to countless students, and it is a great place to grow both as an educator and as a scholar. It is also really great that young people entering the field of higher education can have a chance here to learn from other faculty, to be fairly evaluated, and to be supported with many opportunities for professional growth and development. I'm an alumna, and I currently work here. I would love for my entire career in higher education to be with the CSU.
cons: The life of an adjunct is just not very rewarding, which is something that rings true across the board at any college or university.  Some semesters there is little to no work, of course, especially for those of us who are newer to the profession.

job_title: in Long Beach, CA
pros:
--Enormous pride in serving the largest public university system in the country
--Interaction with energized students and brilliant faculty
--Established organization throughout the State of California
--Very good recognition in all market sectors: government, business, international
cons:
--Sudden layoffs, firings, "non-retentions" 
--Constant threat of unpaid furloughs, salary reductions
--Fortress mentality, us-against-them
--With the California budget picture being what it is now, CSUCO is a bitterly gloomy and administratively rigid work environment

job_title: UI Designer/Developer in Long Beach, CA
pros: Involved in meaningful work. Great benefits, including health care and work/family balance. Working with colleagues who are smart and care about growth, education, and diversity.
cons: Toxic relations between managers cause a lot of stress for employees. Micromanagement - lack of respect and trust for managers to run divisions as they see fit, or professionals to do their work with autonomy. Bureaucracy - your performance is often not rewarded based on its merits, so doing excellent work or work that is above and beyond your level is not worth the effort. Not a good place for advancement .

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lakeway, TX
pros: The team at CSUMB were extremely welcoming, supportive and knowledgeable about the areas in which they worked.  The benefits are great and HR was more than willing to go over any areas of concern with regards to the employment itself, or differences in the benefits offered.  It was also extremely nice to find a department so supportive of a family/work life balance.
cons: Unfortunately many departments still operate like silos with no real cross-communication.  This was hard as a new employee to deal with when used to open communication in prior jobs.

review_title: Great Learning Opportunities for Upward Mobility
job_title: IT Specialist in Hayward, CA
pros: Since this is an educational institution, there are unlimited ways to get more training and skills in technology, that is paid for by the campus (CSU). There is tuition waiver for courses taken on campus toward another Bachelor's or Master's degree. The CSU will also help pay for courses taken for IT certifications. There is also the opportunity to take online classes and learning from udemy.com or coursera.org if approved by management. It's like self study using ACM's (Association for Computing Machinery) learning section, but you are getting paid for it. Also, you are surrounded by PhD's with industry experience, (biotech, ecommerce, social science statistics, and IT consulting to name a few), who can guide you on how to move up in your career in the public sector or private industry. The overall employee culture is very cordial and welcoming. Diversity is emphasized and opportunities are published for all to apply.
cons: Civil Service pay and payscale is definitely lower, which does not keep up with increasing costs of living in the Bay Area. Most software solutions are enterprise off the shelf, similar to most government bureaucracies. There are still open source opportunities, but big enterprise solutions still rule due to government's traditional relationships with Fortune 500 companies (i.e. Oracle, Microsoft, Google, Cisco, Intel, etc.). Change is slow, sometimes taking years to implement a solution. As a result, there are thousands of employees, so change can't happen as often as most employees like. To be in the midst of constant change and excitement, with potential risks, a mid-sized company or startup would be a better fit than civil service government jobs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good level with a lot of great teachers who are there for you whenever you need them. There is an amazing gym on campus as well.
cons: One of the biggest problem CSUN has is it's problem with a lot of students and it makes finding classes very hard for a lot of the students who are trying to finish fast.

review_title: I enjoyed working for CSU International Programs as the CSU Chico IP Alumni Assistant
job_title: IP Alumni Assistant in Chico, CA
pros: The office was very laid-back and relaxed.  Everyone was very friendly and personable.  The study abroad office at CSU Chico became almost like a family. Management was very flexible. Overall great work atmosphere.
cons: There were not many cons about working for CSU other than there were minimal chances of getting a raise for the position I held. The excuse for the lack of raises is due to the CA budget.

job_title: SharePoint Administrator in Long Beach, CA
pros:
Fabulous people, unbelievable benefits and complete job security. 
This is the place you want to retire from after you have vested! Expect compensation to be 20 % below market. Benefits make up for weak compensation
cons: No chance of ever getting a raise or promotion.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Turlock, CA
pros: Friendly environment between each other. Great location.
cons: Management is always preventing subordinates from moving up in position and having a salary increase. The salary you start when being hired is more than likely the salary you will have for 10 years or more. Upon hired, request a higher salary since you will not see an increase for a long time.

review_title: Good place to work but don't expect much perks.

pros: Large well known institution. Fairly stable and secure if you have been here for a while.  Good people. Good long term benefits. Depending on your management, you can be flexible or not.
cons: Use bad CA budget as excuse for not giving raises in the past 5 or so years even if you are good worker.  Telecommuting is discouraged.  Limit expenses on little things for lower regular people but not for management.

review_title: CSUS is a great school for students that plan on working and taking classes at the same time.

pros: Workplace was very flexible, although a student tutor the job is expected to be flexible anyway. Professors had a good relationship with students and tutors for the most part, which helped create a supportive atmosphere.
cons: Worked here as a student tutor, so did not receive benefits, good wages, or good hours. All this was expected, however the poor wages and hours was also in part due to department under-funding.

review_title: THE WORST JOB I EVER HAD
